definition:
An [*equidigital number*]{} $n$ is an integer with a base $b$
representation of $k$ digits for which the prime factorization uses
exactly $k$ digits (with repeated prime factors grouped with exponents
and the digits of those exponents counted whenever greater than 1).
Regardless of the base, all primes are equidigital. The first few
composite equidigital numbers in base 10 are 10, 14, 15, 16, 21, 25, 27,
32, 35, 49, 64, 81, 105, 106, 111, 112, 115, 118, 119, 121, 122, 123,
129, 133, 134, 135, etc.

[1]{} D. Darling, “Economical number” in [*The Universal Book of
Mathematics: From Abracadabra To Zeno’s paradoxes*]{}. Hoboken, New
Jersey: Wiley (2004) B. R. Santos, “Problem 2204. Equidigital
Representation.” [*J. Recr. Math.*]{} [**27**]{} (1995): 58 - 59.
